Key Match Events: Mark Vientos hit a tiebreaking, two-run single during a five-run outburst in the fifth inning
Jesse Winker and pinch-hitter J.D. Martinez each drove in two runs
Brice Turang went 3 for 4, Jackson Chourio was 2 for 4 and William Contreras had two RBIs
Milwaukee had just taken a 4-3 lead heading into the fifth when manager Pat Murphy removed Freddy Peralta
Starling Marte hit a drive that a leaping Chourio caught at the left-field wall
Tyrone Taylor doubled to left on a flyball Chourio misjudged
Jose Iglesias dove headfirst and beat Payamps to the bag for an infield single, with Taylor racing all the way home from second to tie the game
Mark Vientos hit a two-run single to right
Ashby threw a wild pitch and intentionally walked Pete Alonso to load the bases before Martinez delivered a two-run single to right
Pre-Game Insights: Manager Carlos Mendoza said they celebrated after the win in Atlanta and focused on the next game
Milwaukee had lost 10 of its last 11 playoff games
Jesse Winker, who batted.199 with a.567 OPS for the Brewers last year before bouncing back this season, drew a chorus of boos each time he came to the plate
Milwaukee shortstop Willy Adames exchanged words with Winker after Winker hit a two-run triple in the second
The 20-year-old Jackson Chourio was the youngest player to get two hits in his playoff debut
Post-Match Reflections: Mets' manager Carlos Mendoza said they were not satisfied and wanted to fight until the end
Mets' pitcher Luis Severino said they're not satisfied and want to fight until the end, hoping that end is winning the World Series
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Mets didn't earn a playoff berth until they rallied late from a three-run deficit to win the opening game of a makeup doubleheader in Atlanta on Monday, one day after the regular season was supposed to end
Since Major League Baseball went to the current postseason format in 2022 that features four best-of-three Wild Card Series, the Game 1 winner has gone on to advance in each of the eight series
Only one of those eight series even made it to a winner-take-all third game
Milwaukee has lost 10 of its last 11 playoff games, a stretch that began with its Game 7 home defeat against the Los Angeles Dodgers in the 2018 NL Championship Series
